rComments: Prof Rayter's lectures were insightful and brought about ideas that I hadn't thought much of myself. Though I put a lot of effort into my essay and both tests, the grades did not reflect. I found that myself and classmates were disappointed with our grades -- this however may just be becasue of TA marking. Good prof but not satisfied w/ mark

There are many good profs at UofT but Prof. Rayter is NOT one of them. He is dull, boring, and pretentious and does not provide adequate feedback on assignments. His lectures are equal parts inconsistent, scatter-brained, and self-indulgent. I would recommend he find himself another career-path and that you find yourself another English class!

Loved his lectures. I would call them sprawling rather than unfocused, and if you pay attention you will learn not only the stuff you 'signed up to learn' but much more. He is immensely knowledgeable in history, art history, and film just as much as literature, and is very funny to boot.

In my four-year undergrad, I have never had a need to Rate a professor. However, Scott Raytor is without a doubt the most incompetent professor I have encountered. His three hour (mandatory) classes are uninteresting, unnecessary, and uninformed. He does not reply to emails and is not in his office during office hours. In short, a horrible prof.

Scott is one of the worst profs I had come across. He is condescending towards students in class, closed minded, ideologically driven, and has far too high of an opinion of himself. He rambled in lectures or played hour long videos wasting instruction time. Also grades participation harshly without a fixed rubric. Avoid at all costs.
teacherRatingTags: ["Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Tough grader', 'Get ready to read']

rComments: Scott Rayter is a gem and he is hands-down one of the best professors U of T has. He is knowledgeable on a variety of topics and is available any time to help students struggling with themes in the course. Also, it should be noted that In JSU325, he picks books that have really strange, but beautiful premises.

While I enjoyed the content of this course, Scott's lecturing style was rather vague and confusing, often lacking a cohesive and organized structure. He would often go on unrelated rants and, for the first half of the course, would rarely go beyond the first hour of class or would cancel class altogether. Overall, he was disappointing.
teacherRatingTags: ['Graded by few things', 'Get ready to read', 'Tough grader']

rComments: Content of this course was interesting but it would be really hard to pay attention because he would go on these rants I wish he was a bit more specific about what he wants from you in essays Also don't expect to get your marks back for weeks. Still haven't received my final mark and its second semester Otherwise pretty easy going

The lectures are kind of all over the place. He is nice but I could never stay concentrated during his lectures because he went on too many tangents/was a boring lecturer. He seems pretty approachable though. Not bad, not the best.

He's absolutely brilliant. He cares so much about what he teaches and he's very, very compassionate and kind. His lectures are engaging and interesting and I highly recommend going to his office hours. He has so much information and feedback to offer.
teacherRatingTags: ['Gives good feedback', 'Clear grading criteria', 'Accessible outside class']

rComments: Rayter talks about certain genre and rhetorical conventions briefly, but not much depth  in them overall. Close-readings are mostly vague - "This passage talks about sexuality." He's a really funny guy, but he can be very cold and condescending to students. Readings could be better, but they were doable. Assignments lacked explanation, but were ok.
It was refreshing to learn from a professor that genuinely cares about the subject matter and his students. He is passionate about his work and is clear in his lectures.
teacherRatingTags: ['Caring', "Skip class? You won't pass.", 'Get ready to read']

rComments: This guy really likes to go on unnecessary tangents that hold no meaning to the course. Very boring.
teacherRatingTags: ['Accessible outside class', 'Get ready to read', 'Participation matters']

rComments: Really enjoyed his lectures, always entertaining and never textbook cut and paste

Scott was such a lightweight lecturer compared to the standard of professor I'm used to at U of T. His lecturers were often disorganized and vague, students with more knowledge would frequently correct him on facts. Some of the material involved was very complex but Scott's style of lecturing was more high school then anything else.
Very cool and helpful. Gives students autonomy and confidence. A real experience.
Scott's a great lecturer. He's very knowledgeable in his field. He can go off topic at times, and his lectures can seem VERY LONG! But overall, great professor :)

He is an incredible lecturer despite the fact that the subject matter can be dull (the readings tend to be repetitive and data heavy but that's to be expected with an entry level course). You have to buy his book, Queerly Canadian, for this course.. I borrowed from a friend (some people claim to have an undying bond with QC but I could care less).

I really disliked Rayter's class. I found his lectures lacked the depth that I have found in most Eng courses at UofT, partly because the focus always seemed to be on connections to sexual diversity, which I understand is important, but there is so much that we didn't talk about. I found him disappointing and I wouldn't take a class with him again.
Great Prof! Lots of enthusiasm, energy, and attitude (but he backs it up with legit knowledge). Very approachable and funny, made class entertaining and sparked an interest.
for essays and exam prep (if he distributes the questions before hand) then utilize his office hours because he'll give arguments that you can use to approach your essays

He is such a good lecturer. I love the material he covers in his class and there is nothing boring about him. I never fall asleep! I honestly think every cop and politician should have to take one of his classes.

Great prof. Makes it fun to attend class. Does a good job considering how much material is covered in 1 semester. Has a way of explaining complex concepts with simplicity and humour. Definitely recommended!

I agree with the comment directly below. Rayter is a good professor, however, I feel like he's been teaching the course for too long - he seems quite uninterested with the material. Although I did very much enjoy the videos and readings.

This professor knows his stuff. The biggest problem I had was lack of clarity in class discussions. I found a lot of the discussions in class messy and therefore my notes were not very sufficient when it came to exam time, the only class I've encountered this problem in.

Why he is so popular I will never know. Yes, he encourages class discussion but because he allows EVERYONE to talk in class, classes get out of focus and end up feeling disjointed, all-over-the-place, and having no depth. I wish he would give less historical background and talk about what the texts actually convey. He's cute, but honestly overrated

It's hilarious that some of you people are criticizing Rayter, yet you can't spell simple words like "you're" and "realized" correctly. He is a very good professor, and there is a reason his 300-level classes this year have waiting lists that are larger than the classes themselves. He marks hard, but he marks fair.

Very knowledgeable and passionate about queer literature. I found him very considerate of other students' opinions and never made someone feel inadequate in any way. He's also very informal, which was a nice change.

He was one of my fave profs this year. He really knows his stuff. I liked most of the books on the reading list. I appreciated his lecture style - he didn't talk at us for 2 hours straight, he always asked for our input and thoughts. He never put down anyone's opinions either. Hope to take more of his courses!

A good professor, but his lectures started getting boring after an hour. (He swore a lot. Makes a good drinking game.) A little stand-offish (didn't seem to care about talking to students) and full of himself, not unlike most professors at UofT.

"yeah, for sure", "yes, pretty much", "yes, and again", "yes, what else".This is what he says during the entire course... PLUS it doesn't even seem that he's listening to you when you are talking. He looks around, read his papers, and check the window when the students are talking most of the time...bad professor...

One of the top three worst profs I have had at U of T.  All I can say is etc etc etc. You will hear this, "etc etc etc" a minimum of 5000 times during a lecture. I always tried to figure out what he was abriviating and then ralized he had nothing to say. Negative man. Comes across okay but lectures left a lot to be desired. Hard marker, bad person.

Great prof! Very insightful ideas and makes readings interesting by linking them to modern ideas/contexts. He's a tough marker, but will reward insightful and original thought. Funny, but can be a little stand-offish, but I loved that he didn't take any crap!!!

Dr. Rayter is a very critical professor. He expects you to write as if you can read his mind. He is a tough grader. His choice of texts are amazing and are probably the only reason I did not drop the course. Lectures are interesting but usually die out halfway through the 3hour lecture and it just gets tedious and repetitive.

Did a very good job teaching difficult material, led discussions well but also piped in with his own more authoritative opinions. His enthusiasm in the works was contagious. Gave great feedback on essays.

Darth Rayter gives outstanding feedback on essays and presentations.  If your an undergrad looking to improve your writing he can offer much guidance.  He is always tackling new exiciting courses and thoroughly comprehends his material.  He is one of the few professors I've had that clearly goes an extra mile for each student's evaluation.
By far the most inspiring professor I've had at UofT.

He is very passionate about this course material and he is a very good lecturer but I sometimes found his conclusions to be misdirected or limited.  He does have really interesting insights and his questioning lecture style gives students confidence in their ideas.  The readings were great and the films were so revealing.  Tutorials were useless.
very easy going

Definitely one of the best & most entertaining profs I've had yet. I was so not looking forward to taking a course in Can Lit, but he picked really good works to study, so I'm liking it. He's funny, charismatic, and a fair marker.

Scott Rayter is an amazing prof, always looked forward to his lectures, extremely smart, modern, funny, without trying to hard, good choice of readings and excellent choice of films...tests and papers were always fair and graded in good time.
I love this class. Dr. Rayter has been my favourite U of T professor thus far!

Excellent prof all around. Knows what he ius talking about. Young and modern. Not boring. Funny. Does not force particiaption. If u attend lecture and pay attention the tests are easy. No matter how wrong your answer or comment is he tries to validate it. Makes class enjoyable. Lectures are interesting. Good choice of course material.
He was a tough marker in ENG359Y... other than that, an inspiring and enthusiastic lecturer (seemed to get high from standing and lecturing to his class!).
An excellent prof! His lectures are alive, and the material was interesting. He is also very approachable. One of my favourite profs at UofT!
Unclear and unhelpful.
No Comments

Knows his****e, knows how to talk. Probably most endearing is how he tends to look up to the fluorescent lighting for divine guidance to his thoughts. Fascinating."In the old man-killing parishes/ I will feel lost,/ Unhappy and at home." Take his classes. Return to the home you never had.
so great!  brilliant and easy to listen to.
